ticket.description:
If you set the number of webworkers to be used to 30, uploading works fine with Safari and Chrome, but not with FireFox. Confirmed on UNINETT and DeIC 2.0 test install. Symptom: just nothing happens and nothing is logged.
Set the number of workers to 16 and it also works with FireFox.
Etienne provides following feedback:
The mechanism in a terasender upload is as follows: - a worker requests a job with the terasender job driver - the job driver locks (sets boolean in itself) so it doesn't respond to multiple workers. If another worker tries to access it it tells the other worker to wait. This ensures no chunk is given to two workers. - the driver gives a worker an answer; either "here is a chunk for you" or "nothing more to do".
if this messaging mechanism breaks down nothing will work.
Thoughts: - maybe past a certain number of workers with each worker waiting for .5 seconds, with a lot of workers it may be just waiting? - maybe there's some overflow in the messaging system in FireFox? - upon checking the upload console: every worker is requesting a job. First worker is given file, other worker gets “nothing to do” as a response. Are expected to close. First worker doesn’t even signal worker is complete. Past specific number of workers the browser starts to handle events in a bad way. -Is the bug related to max number of workers or to large number of workers combined with async uplods? -what is the breaking number? -maybe there is a limit in the global amount of “work” FireFox can do? That Safari and Chrome doesn’t have? Does messaging just break down?
Etienne will take following actions: - test to see if there is a specific fixed breaking point in # webworkers - check Mozilla email list for similar issues and write email asking others if they've seen similar things - post on Stack overflow
This is not a high priority issue at the moment: just don't set the #webworkers to 30 does the trick. But we need to figure out what causes this. If it's a firefox bug it should be fixed. If it is some issue in our code it should be fixed.
For the 2.0-alpha we will -unless we find out what causes it- label this as a known issue for now.
ticket.summary: FireFox upload hangs with 30 workers

A reload of the page will fix that but we probably should add some 'cache buster' to important .css and .js files that contain crucial definitions. ticket.description:
As reported by Dick Visser: In several places PDOStatement::rowCount was used with a SELECT statement. This seems to work OK for Posgres and MySQL, but it does not for SQLite. From http://php.net/manual/en/pdostatement.rowcount.php:
"For most databases, PDOStatement::rowCount() does not return the number of rows affected by a SELECT statement. Instead, use PDO::query() to issue a SELECT COUNT(*) statement with the same predicates as your intended SELECT statement, then use PDOStatement::fetchColumn() to retrieve the number of rows that will be returned."
ticket.summary: PDO rowCount Query Fixes

ticket.description:
If this transfer option is set with a valid URL the user is redirected to this URL on transfer uploading completion rather than being presented with the "upload complete" dialogue.
This transfer option can not be set in the UI, it needs to be set with an API call.
The use case is using a separate FileSender service to upload big files to a digital exam system. * a student uses a digital exam to hand in an exam * the student wants to attach a file to the exam system by way of an external filesender service * on clicking the "attach big file" link the digital exam system creates a guest voucher for that particular student/exam session and redirects the user to the guest invitation URL. In the guest invitation the transfer option "redirect_url_on_upload_complete" is set to the digital exam system * the user uploads the file, on upload complete the user is redirected back to the digital exam system * the digital exam system downloads the file to its own repository
ticket.summary: Transfer option: redirect_url_on_upload_complete

ticket.description:
form autofill (autocomplete) is not working. This turns out to be correct, it doesn't work when you POST using a script.
After discussion with Chris there look to be two complementary ways of solving this.
1. make a hidden form that posts to a hidden iframe or something, to ensure the form data is saved locally in the browser 2. use jquery autocomplete and query the files database for all To: addresses the particular user has sent to in the past. Present that in a selectable list that's easy to grasp and use.
The one issue with (2) is that it becomes less functional should a site operator choose to prune the database for old records. We can present that in a positive way "we do this to ensure your address list is always up to date and never polluted with addresses that don't work". I don't really know what the user expectation would be so suggest we ask around a bit and try out.
Note: when doing (2) we have to check whether and what kind of database optimisations are needed (!)
ticket.summary: form autofill (autocomplete) not working

ticket.description:
Document the workflow for how we go from feature suggestion to feature release, including where we docuent the various steps.
The current process I envision after 2.0:
- we have a list of feature suggestions somewhere - at some point in time we start working on a new release. For example release 2.1. - release 2.1 will have a number of feature tickets under it. - once we pick up on a suggestion we mark the suggestion as "underway" in the feature suggestion list and relate it to the relevant feature implementation ticket - in the feature suggestion list the feature is closed once the feature is implemented.
A challenge at the moment is that we have a feature suggestion forum at uservoice and a list of suggested features in Assembla. These should be consolidated at some point in time. A challenge with this is that Uservoice has removed its free offer from its pricing structure. At the moment we can still use it but I don't feel comfortable this'll last forever. In any case it is not a desirable situation to be in.
Remember to include "language string freeze" in the process to get from alpha to release (!)
ticket.summary: Document feature suggestion -> implementation workflow

ticket.description:
OpenIdP will be phased out per 1 January 2016. I've verified internally at UNINETT that the entire OpenIdP service will disappear, it also will not be accessible for me as a UNINETT employee. AFAIK there are no current alternatives available that do the exact same.
The FileSender project uses openidp.feide.no as an IdP for the following purposes:
1. test accounts for (automated, selenium-based) client-side testing. 2. ensuring federated login is tested before we release 3. as the default IdP new FileSender installations can authenticate against. This ensures the 1-hour setup time. 4. as a self-registration user account system for demo (test) instances
Considerations with the purpose 1, use for test accounts: - the credentials need to be able to be exposed to external services without problems, like selenium service providers. Credential exposure should not lead to possible compromise of other services - we need to be able to specify which email addresses are associated with the test accounts
Considerations with purpose 3, use by new FileSender instances to test their installation - no default username/password should be distributed with a FileSender release
We will need to find a (combination of) alternative(s).
ticket.summary: Find alternatives to OpenIdP accounts

ticket.description:
Add feedback email handling script and bounce handling related default config.
Script can be called as :
php cron/emailfeedback.php [options] [sources]
options are : * --remove_after_processing : remove file after processing * --move_after_processing[=target] : move file to target folder after processing, if no absolute target will be considered to be under source folder, if no target given "done" source subfolder is used by default
sources can be (several may be used at the same time) : * a path to a file containing a rfc822 message * a path to a folder containing rfc822 message files * - to get rfc822 message from standard input
if no sources are defined standard input is used by default
New config parameters related to bounce handling :
report_bounces, bounces reporting mode, possible values are : - null / false / 0 : bounce reporting disabled (bounces are still saved and displayed in ui, just not reported by email) - asap : report every bounce right away (default) - daily : compile a daily report for each transfer/guest (handled by cron/cron.php) - asap_then_daily : bounces in a time range (see report_bounces_asap_then_daily_range) after transfer/guest creation are reported right away, bounces comming after are reported daily
report_bounces_asap_then_daily_range, time range for asap reporting in asap_then_daily bounce reporting mode, in seconds, defaults to 15 minutes
Files Affected: A /filesender/branches/filesender-2.0/cron/emailfeedback.php M /filesender/branches/filesender-2.0/includes/ConfigDefaults.php
Commit from user: etiennemeleard
............................................................................. More details at: https://www.assembla.com/code/file_sender/subversion/changesets/3271
ticket.summary: Add documentation for bounce handling (general explain + config directive)

ticket.description:
Add to general API documentation (?) and config directives if needed.
"Add a way to use webservice as a remote user (!= remote application).
It must be enabled using the auth_remote_user_enabled configuration parameter (boolean, false by default).
It uses a signed request (same as remote applications), the only difference is that each user have its own secret (stored as a preference).
Secrets can be automatically generated by setting auth_remote_user_autogenerate_secret configuration parameter to true (false by default).
It will allow to setup per-user based trust relationships between a filesender instance and other, potentially non-web based, applications.
Use case is a Thunderbird plugin which allows to put big files on filesender, user installs the plugin and give its secret to it, then the plugin can upload files on behalf of the user.
Sample php client has been updated to be able to use either remote application or remote user authentication.
Files Affected: M /filesender/branches/filesender-2.0/classes/auth/Auth.class.php A /filesender/branches/filesender-2.0/classes/auth/AuthRemoteUser.class.php M /filesender/branches/filesender-2.0/classes/data/User.class.php A /filesender/branches/filesender-2.0/classes/exceptions/AuthRemoteUserExceptions.class.php M /filesender/branches/filesender-2.0/includes/ConfigDefaults.php M /filesender/branches/filesender-2.0/scripts/client/FilesenderRestClient.class.php M /filesender/branches/filesender-2.0/scripts/client/FilesenderRestClientExample.php

Add a configurable user profile page (disabled by default).
The goal is to create a framework for user preferences managment.
To enable it set the "user_page" configuration parameter to an array containing <preference_id> : <view_mode> pairs.
View modes can be "read", "write" or false (same as not set, that is will not be displayed).
Supported preferences are :
- lang (requires lang_userpref_enabled to true) : supports read and write - auth_secret (requires auth_remote_user_enabled), supports only read - created, supports only read

ticket.description:
Date: Tue, 13 Jan 2015 14:20:18 From: etiennemeleard <file_sender@alerts.assembla.com> Reply-To: filesender-alerts@filesender.org To: "filesender alerts user adminned by Jan (filesender-alerts)" <filesender-alerts@filesender.org> Subject: [filesender-alerts] [Assembla] [File sender] Changeset [3400]: Adding an option to get a link for download instead of sending to recipient (disabled by default). Parts/Attachments: 1 Shown 48 lines Text 2 OK 38 lines Text ----------------------------------------
Changeset alert by etiennemeleard in project FileSender
.............................................................................
Adding an option to get a link for download instead of sending to recipient (disabled by default).
When using this an anonymous recipient is created (that is, without email) and its download link is given back to the uploader at the end of upload.
When using this option the user can embbed the link in any mail of his choice (newsletter for example), all downloads are obviously counted as done by the single anonymous recipient.
This mode will be helpful for people wanting to use their FileSender server from another application (like big attachments handling in mail clients).
This option must be enabled in the transfer_options configuration associative array under the name get_a_link (advanced mode is ignored as well as default).
Also adding user id in user page (if enabled).

Since at least two weeks ago (half-way in May) uploads with FireFox and Chrome stopped working with the current 2.0 prototype (see https://terasender.uninett.no/)
They still work on the FileSender 1.6 code though. That seems to indicate it's not directly related to the terasender upload code. I do remember Jack implemented a new way for processing progress events from web workers in 2.0. This meant that progress events when using FireFox or Chrome came a lot more often, which worked especially well with large uplaods or uploads over slow lines.
My guess is something changed in the way FireFox and Chrome deal with progress events in web workers. This bug does need to be found & fixed after the class refactor is done.

ticket.description:
This allows to interrupt the service for database upgrade or even server restart without breaking uploads.
When switched on: - all pages are replaced with the maintenance page - webservice returns specific exception to all requests - clients display a popup explaining what happens - clients pause uploads and put all requests they were about to make in a stack - clients starts to query the server on a regular basis to see if maintenance ended (server responding with no exception status) - when server exits maintenance mode clients restart uploading and run stacked requests and remove maintenance popup
Config directive is config parameter "maintenance" that is boolean and false by default.
implemented in ticket #1182.
ticket.summary: Admin: maintenance mode
Ask for open source unlimited plan for filesender project in POedit

Backend e.g. dom pdf is used to generate audit trails in PDF format. Front-end a number of JavaScript libraries are used, e.g. JQuery.
These 3rd party modules need to be listed on a separate page, with URLs to project, to how we can see current version and how how we can track them. We also should indicate which versions of these modules are included in a specific release.

ticket.description:
Currently FileSender checks for each chunk whether the user has a login session at the IdP. This is unfortunate as the IdP controls when that session times out. Experience from the Norwegian install show that uploads lasting longer than 8 hours suffer from session timeout at the IdP: the Norwegian identity federation IdP has a timeout after 8 hours.
There are several factors in SimpleSAMLphp that the SP controls but one it doesn't: SessionNotOnOrAfter is sent in the SAML response from IdP to SP. Olav Morken writes:
" It is also sent from the IdP to the SP, in the "SessionNotOnOrAfter" attribute. The SP is supposed to use this to determine when the session expires. In practice, this means that the IdP can force the SP to reauthenticate more often than whatever the SP has set in 'session.duration'. "
https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups=#!topic/simplesamlphp/ERlbkoFpntw
It's the SessionNotOnOrAfter that bites us. The implication is that when a FileSender upload lasts longer than SessionNotOnOrAfter ( 8 hours in Norway) the user gets a "you're no longer authenticated" message.
A solution is to change how FileSender deals with this: define a FileSender valid upload session, that remains valid for as long as an upload runs. Only *after* the upload is completed will the IdP be asked again whether the user still has a valid session. This means an upload will complete and should the user want to upload another file, a new session needs to be established if the old one has expired.
A big advantage with pulling control over upload session validity into FileSender. Xander reports this should not be too complicated.
Xander's list of points of consideration: - be aware of session hijacking etc. The "FileSender valid upload session" should only be valid for a specific browser/client upload that started after normal authentication. Probably a combination of sessionId and unique upload token (something we already have?) - such an upload token needs its own expiry, e.g. if 15 minutes without a new chunk then lose validity as AuthN token - what to do with the combination uploadcomplete and timedout SSP-session? We need to present "your upload has completed" page.
xander, please check the description and modify where needed.
ticket.summary: Modify session validity check on upload to allow for very long uploads

ticket.description:
we need a way to offer a user a one-click download of all available files in a transaction. On-the-fly zip seems the best way to do this as long as there is no stable fileWriter API. There are multiple ways for doing this.
In any case there should be no compression as that'll eat CPU for no practical purpose.
ticket.summary: investigate best option for on-the-fly zip of downloads

ticket.description:
With the Snowden revelations fresh in mind FileSender allows any person or organisation using it to subject its data to only the intelligence organisations of it's choosing. Following well established engineering principles "what isn't there can't be abused" FileSender ought to be optimised to minimise the data privacy footprint of its users. This also minimises possible exposure in case a FileSender instance should be compromised.
This means logging least possible, by default deleting possibly sensitive logging in a timely fashion and in general ensure FileSender admins don't have (easy) access to privacy sensitive information. It also means deleting privacy sensitive entries from the database, either by anonimising the privacy sensitive bits (like we did in the stats module) or by deleting them.
In particular we need to remove data that details communication meta-data: who sends what to whom. It's probably OK to have such an overview on the institutional/domain level, but not on personal level. When should it be purged? After expire of the file/transaction or based on a time limit? What about the audit trail? Once purged, the audit trail disappears. How does this work with the database being backup-ed? What about sending the audit trail as an email to the sender? What about making an "incognito" transaction?
A number of FileSender features depend on having historical data available: -auto-complete in the To: field -the audit trail for a sender of a file, especially in the cases where the user chose to not receive emails of the file downloads -other?
The audit trail might be an important one, with anecdotal evidence and logging suggesting a number of users use FileSender in particular for the email receipts. A straight forward solution is to simply gather the audit trail in an email and send it to the sender of the file on purge of the record. That way the audit trail is where it belongs (transaction owner) and it's not with us.
We need to think this through carefully but do need to address it in our 2.0 release. We also need to check up on the EU plans on the data privacy directive update that's underway now, it would be great to already be fully compliant :)
Comments are very much appreciated.
ticket.summary: Minimise FileSender data privacy footprint

ticket.description: Format all 2.0 files excep for the ones /pages and /www according as per our coding conventions: https://www.assembla.com/spaces/file_sender/wiki/Coding_conventions

ticket.description:
With every release we have had and will have known issues: stuff we know is broken but we either will not (lack of resources/priority) or can not (3rd party issues) fix. We kept track of these issues so we could try and fix them in new releases. So far we've done this with putting an issue in the "Deferred" state: an issue is deferred to a later time. However, deferred is an open ticket status. I have a strong desire to be able to close milestones; it makes it much clearer what we are working on and what not. This would also allow us to start using Assembla for more than ticket adminstration; we can start using its project management features to have better control over our efforts.
As an example: release 1.1 and 1.5 we are not working on. Tickets in those milestones will never be worked on again. Still they remain open.
What I want is: - a milestone per release and the ability to close milestones we no longer work on - a record of known issues per release without those issues remaining open tickets after we've decided we will not work on them for that particular release.
Any change of the policy for dealing with known issues will need to be updated in the ticket status guide https://www.assembla.com/spaces/file_sender/wiki/Ticket_Status_Guide
ticket.summary: Establish policy for dealing with known issues

ticket.description: We want to use a translation crowd-sourcing service like poeditor.com. These services typically support a number of formats. We need to decide which format we can/will use in FileSender 2.0 and then make the necessary code changes. This ticket is to support the decision process: which format to use. Etienne, could you please write your input in the comments? Once a decision has been made, please create another ticket for the actual code conseequenses :)
ticket.summary: Decide on language file format to use

ticket.description:
our release policy states a release candidate will be field-tested on at least two FileSender release candidate test sites: - Production sites with at least X transfers by X unique users per day. - The sites run with well-known configurations making what are considered standard features available to their user bases.
for a release candidate to become a production release it needs to have been running production traffic with live users for at least two weeks on at least two release candidate test sites and shown no significant issues impairing service for the users, it can become the production (major) release.
This implies we need at least to FileSEnder release candidate sites. A site would need to install a release candidate within a certain number of time after release, for example a week. A release candidate site should typically get a heads up at least 2 weeks in advance before release.
Preferably we would have a similar mechanism for beta testing sites so we get some organised feedback on the quality of a beta. However, the release candidate sites are more important.
ticket.summary: Establish list of beta and release candidate sites

ticket.description:
Three things:
-figure out which attributes are needed from each federation we're currently looking at -document this in the software documentation -document this on a assembla page (under Documentation?)
ticket.summary: Document which attributes are needed from a federation

ticket.description: The email advising that a file has been downloaded is generated when one clicks on the "Start Download" button, not when the download finishes. This give the impression that a recipient has downloaded the file, even if they clicked on "Cancel" rather than "Save File" when prompted. This could result in the uploader prematurely manually deleting an uploaded file, thinking that their recipient has already downloaded it.
ticket.summary: Download email generated even if user clicks on "Cancel" rather than "Save File"
Add DNS lookup to log entries. Must be configurable switch (togle on/off)

ticket.description:
Note: when the quick fix is implemented for 1.5/1.0.1, this ticket should be relabeled to "under development 2.0".
I got a number of user reports about a file upload that went through just fine but the file seemed to be automatically deleted when you tried to download it. So upload went fine, move went fine, email was sent out, download screen popped up, but download went bad. Nothing significant in the logging.
After observing what goes on on our system I made these observations: observations:
1. on our install the php temp upload directory is set to /tmp rather then to /data/filesender/tmp 2. our FileSender files directory is /data/filesender/files 3. /tmp and /files are on different partitions. That means that a move is an actual transfer, rather then just flipping a pointer in an inode. 4. our cleanup (expiry) cronjob ran every 5 minutes
This means the move from temp dir to filesender files dir takes time. With an 1.5 GB file this might intersect with the cronjob running. If I read the cronjob's code correctly, it checks for files that do exist in the filestore but do not have a database entry associated with them. If it founds such files, it deletes them. In possibly the same cronjob run, it then notices a stale database entry that is then set to "closed".
Presto, the file has disappeared for the user.
The problem affects both 1.0.1 and 1.5. There is a quick fix under discussion, which in practice will prevent the problem from occuring unless you configure your site explicitly to trigger it. The ultimate solution has to wait for a redo of the database schema in the post-1.5 development work.
ticket.summary: Race condition with file deletion cronjob under certain circumstances
Error if locale does not exist in locale.php

ticket.description:
The current log table grows and grows and grows.
A scheduled periodic cleanup that throws away entries older than <configurable log-retention period> needs to be implemented. Deployment wise this fits nicely after we have the working anonimizer (part of the statistics module). That way we can keep the log data relevant for statistics, and throw away the non-anonimised logging. A default retention period of 6 weeks sounds sane.
A first thought for implementation: make it part of the existing clean-up cronjob (found in filesender/cron/cron.php). There's already interaction with the database there. It would save a FileSender admin the hassle of setting up 2 cronjobs.
Thank you Claude Tompers from RESTENA for reminding us about this one.
ticket.summary: cronjob to periodically clean non-anonomised log table

ticket.description: Currenty we have a max. expiry date which happens to also be the default expiry date. I'd like to see these two separated, so I can configure them to different values. Use case: I have customers who'd like to see a longer expiry time, but at the same time I'm pretty sure not all would like to see such a longer expiry time.
ticket.summary: Separate default-expiry-date and max-expiry-date

Since inserting a not-compliant 'filefrom' should not happen in normal workflow I prefer generating an 'err_invalidemail' validation error .

ticket.description:
When the PHP mail() call (in classes/Mail.php) fails (for whatever reason) it returns 'false'. The sendEmail function returns this result to the various callers but that result is not always checked or used for user-feedback. This needs improvement.
- consistently check and use the sendEmail return value - do this before logging or reporting a succesfull insert/update/message sent - log failures somewhere? - show an error to the user ('Error sending mail, please contact your administrator' ??)
Note that mail() can fail even after a succesfull insert/update so in general the upload/voucher-creation is OK. We might need a more specific message then, for example with a voucher people should create a new one after the administrator has found and fixed the problem. With an upload a resend should be fine in general (unless the problem was caused by the mail-adresses of course).
Candidate for beta2 if 'easy' but I prefer beta3 to get more testing time.
ticket.summary: mail sending error handling

ticket.description:
As per the discussion on filesender-dev:
The link to http://caniuse.com/#feat=fileapi from the help page shows the actually needed feature to be able to do HTML5 uploads. However the default link in $config['HTML5URL'] points to a more general HTML5 feature check page.
Quoting Thijs:
"Perhaps this would be a better default for HTML5URL than the current setting: $config['HTML5URL'] = 'http://html5test.com/'; as the caniuse one specifically targets this HTML5 feature and not any possible HTML5 capability."
On a side note: although technically HTML5 is used for large file uploads a user is probably only interested in the answer to the 'larger than 2GB possible?' (yes/no) question. We might consider changing the use of 'HTML5'-enabled to something stating 'Large uploads possible'.
ticket.summary: Feature change request: Default HTML5URL link

But a fine example of how we need to revisit error logging throughout the code, ensuring it is both consistent, it starts to adhere to various "log levels", service-affecting issues are logged in filesender.log and errors in the UI are meaningful.
unable to connect to database and debug=true results in the following (expected) entry in the filesender logfile:
2011/10/12 03:07:09 [Session ID: none] Error: [2] pg_connect(): Unable to connect to PostgreSQL server: FATAL: database "filesende" does not exist : /usr/share/php/MDB2/Driver/pgsql.php [435] [86.62.167.38(86.62.167.38)]
unable to connect to database and debug=false results in no entry in the filesender logfile and in the following message to the user:
Fatal error: Uncaught exception 'DBALException' with message 'Error executing query: MDB2 Error: connect failed' in /var/www/filesender-1.5/classes/DBAL.php:280 Stack trace: #0 /var/www/filesender-1.5/classes/Log.php(136): DBAL->exec('? IN...', '', '', 'Error', '', '', '2011-10-12 03:1...', '', '', 'Error executing...', 'a9f348deeaad60f...') #1 /var/www/filesender-1.5/classes/Functions.php(381): Log->saveLog('', 'Error', 'Error executing...') #2 /var/www/filesender-1.5/pages/vouchers.php(134): Functions->getVouchers() #3 /var/www/filesender-1.5/www/index.php(222): require_once('/var/www/filese...') #4 {main} thrown in /var/www/filesender-1.5/classes/DBAL.php on line 280
ticket.summary: Error handling: no error handling when debug=false and database connection failure

ticket.description:
the admin menu, on the "general" tab, currently shows a disk usage meter. It would be useful to add a few gauges for use by webmins who don't necessarily have visibility over the lower-lying systems their filesender is running on:
1) a check to show when CRON was last run -- could read something like "files last flushed on [date/time]" 2) a check to see whether filesender still has connectivity to the SMTP server (an EHLO every 10 minutes would suffice)
ticket.summary: admin tab -- two additional alerts
Windows install documentation?

ticket.description:
In-app messaging: part are generated by client itself during upload process part come from server
When upload is done: if you want to redirect user to transfer page we have to have a way to propagate message through URL. Would need URL parameter which gives message identifier to display and some way to pass parameters: parameter complete but depending on transfer options may need some other things as well.
Could display message in upload page. But would then lose message.
Two-sided problem: in-app messaging area makes sense and easy to do for messages from server using it to also display client-workflow related messages is a challenge.
ticket.summary: Feature: in-app messaging
PHP configuration Documentation

ticket.description:
Consider an audit trail functionality.
One way to implement this is to show a historical MyFiles. Disadvantage: requires audit trail data to hang around. That's contrary our wish to retain least possible sensitive data on the FileSender service.
Another and possibly easier way: once the transaction expires, wrap the entire transaction history in a PDF and ship it to the sender. This PDF could be timestamped and signed to provide strength to the audit trail.
This would be accompanied by a config option that says "always on" or "user override", and in case of the latter would either tick it by default or leave it open by default. A service admin would need to be able to indicate whether this optoin is part of the standard "always show" options or not.
ticket.summary: New feature suggestion: transaction audit trail
File permissions

ticket.summary: Summary tabel of file recipients and actual downloaders *after expiry*

ticket.description:
There is nothing in the documentation on what email-facilities must be on the server hosting filesender. Must it be able to receive? Only send? Send via smarthost? Etc.
Email is being clamped down on because of spam, trojans and viruses (disclaimer, my #1 paid priority is keeping the anti-spam systems up and running) so there might also be relevant to add email-error-checking procedures ala. "everything is set up correctly but mail still can't leave the system".
ticket.summary: document email server requirements

ticket.description:
FileSender now sends "there's a file for you" messages *on behalf of* and *with the From: address* of the file uploader. This will lead to issues for domains that use SPF.
Some possible ways to deal with this: -FAQ entry that sites using SPF that want to use this as a service should put the filesender box in their SPF records -use the FileSender service email address as From:, and put the user's email address in the body of the message. -under the assumption that SPF works on SMTP envelope level, use the FileSender service email address as envelope from (rfc2821 MAIL FROM:), email address of the person sending the file in RFC822 From:
whichever way we choose, seems that some more configurables are needed....
ticket.summary: devise a solution for SPF records
pages ask for media that aren't included (sprites, favicon etc.)

When a file is uploaded to multiple recipients, the backend generates different hash URLs per recipient (which is good) but when a download is completed from one of these distinct URLs, the download notification email does not make a distinction as to which user has downloaded the file. Here as an example is one such notification:
"The File HPIM0346.JPG has just been downloaded by jan.meijer@uninett.no, guido.aben@aarnet.edu.au."
The same notification was received regardless of whether the file was downloaded from the URL made available to Jan, or the URL made available to Guido (which, I repeat, were different URLs).
The end user workflow would be greatly improved upon if the notification email would make a disctinction to reveal exactly from what URL the download had been initiated/completed.
ticket.summary: download notification does not distinguish between users if file uploaded to multiple users

ticket.description:
This was the original issue posted:
====================================================== Date: Thu, 25 Feb 2010 12:46:43 +0100 From: Mario Vandaele <> To: filesender-dev Subject: [filesender-dev] LDAP authentication and multiple e-mail address entries in "mail" attribute
Hello,
Currently I use LDAP authentication/attributes during my tests. I use my organisation's ldap server, which contains multiple e-mail address entries for my "mail" attribute. The 1st is my office e-mail address, but the others are aliases for distribution lists within the organisation. So, whenever I successfully log in, the "From"-field is already filled in with all entries and also stored as such in "filefrom" in "files" table in db. As a consequence the receiver of the files gets to see these entries as well, but when he successfully downloaded the file, then an e-mail is sent to all e-mail entries (=spam,=confidentiality, =major issue). So, my suggestion is to make the "From"-field editable, by which I mean that the parameter value is parsed and a checklist is created with all found e-mail addresses, so you can tick off the ones you do/don't want to use (at least one selected) and then stored as such in the db. ======================================================================
We had similar issues in the Confusa project. Users can have multiple email addresses.
Options the software should have: -take first address -give user option to pick from addresses (display multiple addresses with checkboxes in front) but require at least one address
in both options the From: field would need to be editable.
We would need a configuration option indicating which of the two the software would use.
how does that sound?
ticket.summary: How to handle multiple email addresses from user's LDAP entry

ticket.description:
When using an email address as "x@uninett.no" the Flash UI app comes up with an error like "please select a file for upload". This bug has two issues associated with it:

2. The error is totally wrong!
I know that there are issues with email address handling but at least the error should be appropriate ;)
ticket.summary: Email address with 1 character refused with "Please select file to upload" error

ticket.description:
With version 1.5 we have a multi-language UI. The email templates are still one language. This might be a problem we can not solve.
How do you deal with a Norwegian user sending a file to a Brazilian user? The Brazilian might not want to receive a Norwegian email. A Norwegian email with "english at the bottom" might also not be desirable. Letting people set the language of the recipients sounds cumbersome and would be unwieldy with multiple recipients.
There is no widely deployed mechanism to let an email client pick a locale on behalf of the recipient.
So this problem appears to be a thorny one: we know who the *sender* is, but have no clue about the receiver. The user knows but shouldn't be bothered with questions about that and besides, allowing a user to set a certain attribute of a recipient stimulates the next desire: being able to store such information about recipients. We currently store no permanent information whatsoever and that makes the service very easy to run, which is a characteristic we should think carefully about before giving it up.
ticket.summary: Multi-language email templates [L]

ticket.description: We need to introduce an extra empty line between body and headers to further lower the spam filter count. Turns out to be less trivial in PHP then one would expect. This needs to be looked at lateron
ticket.summary: Emails now score 2.5 on spam filter, introduce empty line between body and headers

ticket.description: Make things such that you can hook multiple identity providers onto FileSender and have a different attribute mapping for each IdP
ticket.summary: Make the IdP attribute mapping configurable when using multiple IdPs
Default Email Subject

ticket.description: At the moment a clean up process runs whenever *a* user logs in. To improve robustness and scalability the clean up process needs to be moved to a cronjob-like solution.
ticket.summary: use cronjob for clean up

ticket.description: Logging is done at two places at the moment. Logging goes into log files and logging goes into a database. I would say that both are needed. Logging to log files makes it easy for a sysadmin to investigate faults in the service. Logging to the database means that a service manager can easily generate custom reports and stats without bothering the sysadmin. But, this needs a thorough rethink for 2.0 so we have some solid and consistent thinking behind our logging mechanism: clear goals for what needs to be achieved that will lead to a clear implementation of logging and loglevels as well as what is logged where (when).
ticket.summary: Overhaul log mechanism

ticket.description:
We use the email address as the GUID. That means that if you can get your CEOs email address in your IdP entry, you have full access to his files on FileSender.
Up until now that didn't matter because well, you could see what files he had there. Then we added the capability to delete. Still didn't matter, but opened for DoS. But from beta-1.10, you can add new recipients to existing uploads. And then it matters. Inadvertent data disclosure sucks.
We're thinking it should be solvable by not using email address but ePPN and/or eduPersonTargetedId.
After some discussion probably what needs to be done is: -add GUID=eduPersontargetedId attribute mapping to config file -use this GUID as the GUID in the app throughout
Note: we really should think of a way to still be able to use OpenId as well?
ticket.summary: email address unsuitable as GUID

ticket.description: Return email notification to Voucher creator and/or file up loader.
ticket.summary: Notification email not being sent back

ticket.description:
When the log directory is missing, or can't be written to, the flash application loads but doesn't display a login button or the splash text. It's fairly easy to debug *once you look in the PHP logging*. Even then, the error reported there requires you to either understand what's going on or dive in the code to figure out exactly which file/directory is missing. That can be done better.
It would be really good if the FileSender app has a better sanity check when starting up, and actually reports back. In the case of a missing log directory, I guess the sane thing to do is to report this through the UI. So giving some sane feedback where an admin can read it.
Thinking a bit more. Usually you want all error logging to go to the error log. There are two things in particular that can not be logged to the error log.
1. config file parsing error 2. logfile not writable
These two circumstances should simply be reported through the UI?
ticket.summary: improve feedback when log directory is missing

Files over approximately 4 GB get the wrong size. Up to 3.96 GB it goes just fine, a 4GB file is reported to be 64.47 MB. A 16GB file is reported as 3.35 GB. This might have an impact on the upload. It at the least confuses users.
Addendum: this looks to be an issue in the Flash UI. I see the same miscalculation in the 'uploaded file size' of the Uploaded Files tab in the Admin interface.
ticket.summary: size calculation wrong for larger files

ticket.description:
In filesender/classes/AuthSaml.php, line 61.
It reads:
if(stristr($config['admin'], $attributes[$config['saml_uid_attribute']]) === FALSE) {
It should read:
if(stristr($config['admin'], $attributes["eduPersonTargetedID"]) === FALSE) {
Based on the test logic further up in the function. I suspect the test "if(isset($attributes[$config['saml_uid_attribute']][0])) {" above it at line 57 needs to be fixed to properly accommodate the scenario where if we're not setting the uid attribute in the config (say we're not using EPTID).
It may accidentally work, but the types are wrong, for in our case the saml_uid_attribute is coming back as an array, and stristr will take an integer or a string, but not an array.
ticket.summary: saml_uid_attribute parsing code not 100%

ticket.description:
We publish our downloadable release tarballs in the Assembla file store. Assembla does not offer us any way to see how often files get downloaded or by which IP address. We would like to have that information to get some idea on how popular the software is and where's it in use.
To solve this we'll arrange for a separate webserver 'download.filesender.org'. It'll only serve up the tarballs.
reachable by:
download.filesender.org downloads.filesender.org
pointing to same DocumentRoot.
Doing both HTTP and HTTPS.
Chris, myself, Guido and others (possibly) involved in release process can upload files.
Site will have a weblog analysis tool shielded by .htaccess so we can see what's going on.
ticket.summary: Arrange download(s).filesender.org

ticket.description:
the default value for the "max_email_recipients" config value is rather low, at 4. Please increase this default to a much higher value, e.g, 100 Also, please allow the config value of "0" (zero) to signify "no limit"; this needs to also be reflected in the commentary to the config value in the config file.
e.g.
$config["max_email_recipients"] = 100; // maximum email addresses allowed to send at once for voucher or file sending; a value of 0 (zero) is interepreted as "no limit"

ticket.description:
If you do this:
-upload a file -go to 'my files' -with 'add recipient' add a recipient, say "John"
John receives the email with the download link. Clicks on the link, and the download does not work. No feedback in the client as to why not.
The Apache error log shows what's going on: [Thu Jun 17 16:30:59 2010] [error] [client 158.38.62.126] File does not exist: /var/www/filesender/www/files/null0148.JPG
So it looks like the resulting file pointer is screwed up when adding a new recipient.
The bug is actually two issues: 1. the fact that the file is not downloadable 2. the missing error message to the user about the server side error.
ticket.summary: MyFiles -> Add Recipient: download link in resulting file voucher does not work

ticket.description:
The gears upload uses the tmpfiles directory to store the uploaded chunks under the 'orignal filename'. When two separate users/sessions are uploading a file with the same filename the chunks are added to a single file in the tmpfiles directory. This leads a.o. to corrupt files and information leakage. Solution would be to use a unique (user-dependent?) identifier (either a subdir or prefix for the filename).
How to reproduce (at least on 0.1.13 and 0.1.14):
take two *different* files (reasonably large so that it takes a while to upload) and give them the same name (i.e. testfile.tst). Have two users (or 1 user and two separate browsers/machine) upload the file (one user/browser one of the two files, the other user/browser the other) at the same time. Compare the resulting files after upload (check size and md5sum).
ticket.summary: gears upload tmpfile handling

ticket.description:
Currently files are marked deleted and rendered inaccessible on expiry/deletion. But the actual deletion is run on login of the next user. This should be made more predictable. probably through use of a time-based process: say a cron job that runs once every hour to delete what needs to be deleted. Users want to know *when* their file is actually thrown away.
Come to think of it: rather then deleting we might want to advise proper 'secure deletion' of a file to make sure no remnants remain.
ticket.summary: Modify file deletion process

ticket.description: With MyFiles: Add Recipient it is possible to give a different expiry date for the new recipient(s) of the file. However if this new expiry date is shorter than the expiry dates of the other recipients the expiry process in the back-end will expire/remove all files, even if the expiry date of those other files hasn't been reached yet.

ticket.description:
At the moment when something goes wrong with a file upload we have insufficient information to figure out where in the client or in the server the problem might be. It's difficult to ask the person with the problem to tell us what went wrong where, reproduce it etc. Better it would be to have proper logging.
To solve this we can implement client-side step-by-step logging that sends a log line to the server for every 'processing step' the client takes. Server side it would result in one logfile per user. Preferably with the username in the filename to make debugging for the server admin easy. The logging would be switched on/off from the server side. Server side a filter based on ePTID would select for which users logging would be maintained. That way you wouldn't get too much of logging on a busy server.
The logging would have to log both the client side steps and the server side steps for that particular user in 1 integrated logfile.
If we have this in the code then even though sometimes things wouldn't work, we at least have a solid handle on where something went wrong.
Different combinations of operating system (version) - browser (version) - flash version have different results and it's difficult to pinpoint exactly what piece of code was responsible for stuff going wrong.
To solve this functionality needs to be imp
ticket.summary: Detailed transaction logging facility per user

ticket.description:
I'm currently using an untuned Windows machine to download a 40GB file from the Australian filesender installation. It took so long for the progress bar to move to 1% that I had to check whether it was actually doing something ;)
I'm thinking: an extra field in the download page that tells a user how many bytes have actually been transferred, and how many are still to go, that might help.
If you look at how FireFox implements this in their current download progress thingie when I'm downloading a Fedora DVD image:
-it says '2% of 1 file - Downloads" -FileName -status (... or Paused) -103 MB of 3.4 GB (9.0 MB/sec) -x minutes remaining
That looks pretty good to me. Note: if we change to HTML5, maybe we get this free of charge by leveraging built in browser functionality?
ticket.summary: Extra field in download page indicating download progress in actual bytes
Email Optional message shows 'r' instead of carriage return

ticket.description:

The download seems to start but only a little bit of data (a few KBytes) is transferred after which nothing happens anymore, no network activity, no progress in the interface. Reproduced with IE8 (latest updates) on Win7 (32bits) and XP and two 'independent' users (Guido and me).
The actual filesize that seems to be the largest size IE8 can download is between 4GB-1M-1K (OK) and 4GB-1M (hangs).
At this moment it is only IE version 8 that has this problem, IE6 works, FF also.
ticket.summary: IE8 download of files > 4GB hangs

ticket.description: Files larger than 4GB are shown with an incorrect size in the Administration Interface (at least in Uploads, Downloads, Complete log). A 10GB file is said to be 2GB, a 4GB file is "NaN undefined" and a ~40GB (42312665238 bytes) file is reported as 3.41GB. This is seen in 0.1.13 and 0.1.14 and with various browsers/platforms. Note that exporting the data gives you an xls file with the correct filesizes. So this looks like a (u)int/Number problem in the display part.
ticket.summary: Large filesizes (>4GB) are incorrectly presented in flash interface

ticket.description:
When downloading large files the download progress bar stops at a certain percentage. It appears that this percentage matches a 2GB limit. For example downloading a 10GB file the counter stops at 20%, 5% with a a 40G file and 33% with a 6GB file. Note that while the counter 'hangs' the download still continues and (on Mac and Linux) also completes. Sometimes (haven't found a pattern yet) the counter (after hanging for a while) suddenly starts again at 0% up unitl the 2GB percentage.
Tested with various browsers (FF, IE, Opera, Chrome) on XP, Win7, OSX and Ubuntu and with the latest two 10.x versions of Flash.
ticket.summary: Download progress bar stops at 2GB

ticket.description:
When downloading large files (larger than 4GB) on Windows (XP or Win7) with various browsers (FF, Opera, Chrome) the downloads essentially seem to fail on a strange 4GB limit in Flash or the Flash app. Symptoms are:
- download starts and a temporary file FlashTmp0.tmp is created - FlashTmp0.tmp grows while downloading - at around 2G downloaded bytes the progress counter 'hangs' (see #255) but the file keeps growing - at exactly 4GB (4294967296 bytes) the FlashTmp0.tmp stops growing - the download itself (network traffic) continues - after the download has finished (i.e. network traffic stops) the display still shows the counter.and the cancel button. Pressing cancel removes the FlashTmp0.tmp file.
Note that the disk/filesystem used to save the download and where the FlashTmp0.tmp is stored is capable of storing large files (> 4GB), better yet, the files larger than 4GB were created on and uploaded from the same filesyetem, downloading the file directly to the disk/filesystem (with a https:.../files/... from the browser) gets you the complete file.
This appears to be a Windows-specific problem, the same large files are downloaded OK on Mac and Linux. Symptoms are seen by at least two independent users (Jan and me) but it might be a good idea if others could try a download of a 4GB+ file on Windows and see what happens (note: don't use IE8, see #249)
ticket.summary: 4GB download limit on Windows ??

ticket.description:
When flash downloads in FireFox with Firebug extension enabled you cannot download more than 1.5Gb or whatever RAM you have available as Fire Bug keeps all the data live in memory recording all the ongoing data transfers.
Solution: Disable Fire Bug Extension if downloading large files.
ticket.summary: FireFox with Firebug Enabled crashes downloads over 1.5Gb

ticket.description:
At the moment there is a problem when the default config.php is changed, the debian package process patches config.php to set default settings and if this file is changed the patch fails.
There are a number of solutions; * leave it as is; make the patch every time config.php changes * Split out config directives into separated files (DB config, location config, etc), this minimizes the chance of change collision * Include a complete copy of config.php in the debian package. Problem here is that if config.php is changed the debian version needs to be revised also.
Probably we will have the same problem for the RPM packages.
ticket.summary: optimizing config.php for distribution

ticket.description:
When (for whatever reason) a gears (chunk) upload is not authenticated anymore fs_gears_upload.php returns the string 'Error' leading to a very generic error message in the flash app (and without server side logging). A more specific message and some server side logging would help (like with the flash upload code?).
Optinally the error message could also give some hints since there are known cases where this error is reached:
- User has disabled third party cookies in FireFox, hint would be to add 'servername' to the list of exceptions (see #236) - Upload took more than the session duration time (this probably can be checked on the server side?), hint would be to either login again and resume the upload or contact the server admin to increase the session duration.
From Beta 1.15
ticket.summary: Error handling with 'unauthenticated' gears upload

ticket.description:
One of the new features is that the files are compared against the DB and outdated files deleted, which is great of course. But unfortunately causes an issue for me.
Would it be possible to add a clause in the config to exclude files/directories from this check? In our setup the files/ directory is a NFS mount on an isilon storage system, and this creates a .snapshot directory, which is mounted read only.
When Filesender loads, it tries and fails to delete this and stops the whole system from working.
As a quick work around I modified line 246 in classes/Functions.php
to exclude .snapshot from being deleted. It's not very elegant but has gotten things up and running.
ticket.summary: exclude folders and files from cleanup cron
Move /files out of www enabled directory

ticket.description: Reported by Nikola Garafolic and confirmed by X. When doing a New Upload on Linux (tested on Ubuntu 10.04.1 with FF 3.6.10 and xul-ext-gears package) files larger than or equal to 2GB (base 1024) can be selected in the 'browse' window but aren't picked up in the interface (i.e., no file is listed as ready to be uploaded). Tested against 0.1.15 and svn r209 (and later).
ticket.summary: File select fails in Linux/Gears for files of 2G or more

ticket.description:
I did note however a 'shoot in the foot' thing when canceling the upload (which was also there before the tmpfile changes I guess) and is most noticable when using larger chunksizes (i.e. 10MB as on my testbox).
When I cancel an upload the UI tells me 'Cancelled upload but in the background Gears is still uploading the last started chunk. With a slow uplink and large chunk sizes that can take a while. On the server this last chunk (still in transit) is not yet appended to the tmpfile so when I resume the upload while gears is still uploading the chunk from the previous attempt that could lead to chunks being sent and appended twice.
The scenario would be in that case that while the previous chunk is still in transit Flex asks for the already uploaded filesize *before* the chunk in transit is appended to the tmpfile on the server. That chunk will thus be sent again but since the one still in transit is also appended to the tmpfile the file on the server will get the chunk twice.
Would it be possible to have the 'Cancel upload' function either wait for Gears to actually finish the chunk being uploaded or have Flex somehow 'kill' the Gears-upload ?
From Beta 1.15
ticket.summary: Gears cancel - needs to complete last chunk before allowing a new upload

Flash upload - clean up correctly on cancel upload.

ticket.description:
When a Flash upload (no gears) takes a long time (for example from a residential ADSL link) the upload can take longer than the PHP session expiry timer (default on debian is 1440 seconds is 24 minutes). During the upload the session-cache file is removed on the server but the upload continues (it started when the session was still valid). After the upload processing the file fails due to the expired session. Also cancelling the upload after the session has expired on the server gives an error:
Error: [256] Invalid session supplied. : /var/www/filesender-0.1.17.201010290059/www/fs_uploadit.php [47]
We could configure a higher value for the session.gc_maxlifetime setting but there are good reasons to keep that value low. Another solution could be to to send some kind of 'keepalive' every now and then from the client to the server during the upload to keep the session 'active'. Note that setting client_specific_logging to true will keep the session active on the server so something similar but less verbose would probably work.
ticket.summary: PHP session timeout with large (long) flash uploads

ticket.description:
On 25.10.2010. 8:55, Nikola Garafolic wrote: > How can file get status "Closed" other than user deleting it or > reaching expiry date? > I have some files that have not expired, and users swear they did not > delete them, but are in "Closed" status, and physically not present > inside filesender files directory. I am refering to version 1.16.1.
I believe we found the reason for this behavior.
In case when filename contains UTF-8 characters field "fileoriginalname" in the database will be different from the name of file stored on the disc. Because of the discrepancy function cleanUp in cron.php will assume that the file was removed and it will put the file status to Closed. This will be performed in the last loop ("// close all entries that do not have a pyhsical file in storage"). File will not be removed immediately but at the next cron.php run (loop "// Loop through the files").
The reason for discrepancy is the following. Field "fileoriginalname" comes from the JSON feed sent by Flash and the actual name comes from the _FILES variable. In case of JSON feed UTF-8 chars will be changed to \uxxxx equivalents by the json_encode. In case of _FILES variable they will simply be turned to "_" by the sanitizeFilename function.
I attached a patch for fs_uploadit.php which turns UTF-8 name from _FILES variable to JSON feed equivalent.
Cheers, emir
ticket.summary: UTF 8 charachters in name deleted by CRON

ticket.description:
Some notes about the actual flash upload limits, independent of the exclamation mark problem but relevant to testing filesizes around 2000M.
Upload of 2000M (base 1024) file of 2097152000 bytes, upload from a Win7 box with Opera, no gears
At the start of the upload I get on the server:
Oct 29 12:43:33 apache2[11765]: PHP Warning: POST Content-Length of 2097152672 bytes exceeds the limit of 2097152000 bytes in Unknown on line 0
simplesamlphp[11765]: Error: [8] Undefined index: Filedata : /usr/share/filesender/www/fs_uploadit.php [62] apache2[11765]: Error: [8] Undefined index: fid : /usr/share/filesender/www/fs_uploadit.php [62] apache2[11765]: Error: [8] Undefined index: Filedata : /usr/share/filesender/www/fs_uploadit.php [62]
After upload the client gets a 'Can not move file' error. It looks like there is no 'tmp' file created on the server. Also note that the Content-Length is 672 bytes larger than the actual filesize of 2097152000. It would be good to catch this error at the start of the upload so users don't have to wait a possibly long time to see that the upload failed.
The advertised limit is 2000M (the post_max_size=2000M limit in PHP.ini): ; Maximum size of POST data that PHP will accept. post_max_size = 2000M
Setting post_max_size=2001 (and a restart of apache!) makes it possible to upload a 2000M file. This should be in the installation notes (setting post_max_size a little bit larger than the upload_max_filesize to allow for extra header info which is included in the POST Content-Length.
As for the maximum filesize with Flash there are two other relevant variables:
In php.ini:
; Maximum allowed size for uploaded files. upload_max_filesize = 2000M i and in the filesender config.php:
$config['max_flash_upload_size'] = '2147483648'; // 2GB
These should match (but don't in the default config) so the user will be warned when uploading more than the the minimum of the two settings. We could explain this in the installation notes or perhaps it is possible to add a check on the (three!) relevant variables and only allow uploads that are less than or equal to the minimum of the three settings (taking into account that the post_max_size should allow for some extra bytes, say a few K).
Either way, the current defaults and installation notes are not consistent and will give problems with flash uploads around and above the 2000M (base 1024).
ticket.summary: Max Upload Size consistency

From a user's point of view the upload failed silently.
It turns out we can reproduce this bug by putting UTF8 characters (øæå etc.) in at least the message field.
We need to test the various cases where people could use non-ASCII characters:
- selected filename - message subject - message text
and those for both flash and gears upload *and* subsequent download (the download of a gears uploaded file currently fails with invalid voucher).
As part of the bug fix we need to implement a check that lets a "bad" or "empty" database insert fail loudly so that we can give the user a "hard error".

Also, I assume that not all the authentication options would need to be listed for a local installation. Note comment above about use of "securely".

ticket.description:
When using 'session_start()' (r372/r251) in download.php a user can only download *one* file at a time with the same browser. This is probably because PHP only allows one script active at a time on a session. This can be an issue when a user downloads a large file taking a long time and also wants to download other files (with the same browser).
This also affects other filesender operations, for example when a user is downloading a large file he/she cannot login or do other authenticated actions because the download script is 'blocking' the session.
How to repeat: start a download of a large file taking a long time. Then try (while the file is downloading) with the same browser to do other actions with filesender (on the same server). They will give you blank screens *until* the download is finished or cancelled.
A solution might be to have download.php to have its own 'session id' for each download. Not sure about the possibilities and/or implications though :(
ticket.summary: download blocks other filesender operations in the same session/browser

ticket.description:
Date: Tue, 30 Nov 2010 12:38:54 +0100 From: Nikola Garafolic <nikola.garafolic@srce.hr> Reply-To: filesender-dev@filesender.org To: filesender-dev@filesender.org Subject: [filesender-dev] email validation in flex
Hi,
Is is possible to implement some sort of email address validation? Users input all kind of bad email address syntax like:
'my.email@domain.com' "my.email@domain.com" name surname <my.email@domain.com> <my.email@domain.com>
Filesender expects email address in the my.email@domain.com form, so all of the above are undeliverable email addresses.
Some sort of regex check like this should be enough:
\b[A-Z0-9._%-]+@[A-Z0-9.-]+\.[A-Z]{2,4}\b
Regards, Nikola
ticket.summary: email address validation in flex

ticket.description:
When using international characters in filenames other than ISO-8859-1 the filename will look 'funny' when downloaded with Internet Explorer and possibly other browsers other than FireFox, Chrome or Safari. The file is however correctly downloaded and usable.
The "Content-Dispositon" problem
At the moment the labeling of a string as UTF-8 encoded is not done when a file containing special characters is downloaded. The download process uses the HTTP Content-Disposition header with a filename parameter. This header is only defined for filenames containing characters from the (single byte) ISO-8859-1 character set.
Although there are currently ongoing standardisation efforts to make it possible to use other character sets there is no universally adopted way of transmitting a UTF-8 encoded filename yet (see http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/draft-ietf-httpbis-content-disp-latest.html for details). The current filesender code therefore relies on what is called 'encoding sniffing' in browsers such as FireFox, Chrome and Safari. Internet Explorer can only handle ISO-8859-1 (single byte) encoded filenames.
See our developer documentation on International_Character_Handling
ticket.summary: Filename with international characters other than ISO-8859-1 will look 'funny' when downloaded with IE

ticket.description:
The goal of quota support is to be able to restrict how many resources a user uses.
Option 1: cumulative upload-size limit: a maximum to the total size of active files a user has on a FileSender install Option 2: time-relative upload-size limit per user: a user can only upload a certain amount of data in a certain time frame Option 3: max. number of uploads in a certain time period
Option (3) sounds illogical: the resource consumed is the amount of disk, not the amount of network sockets. Option (1) might be the most logical one as it offers a user some form of control: if they go over their quota, they can encourage the downloader to download quickly so they get free upload slots again.
It ought to be a system-wide setting, one size fits all. User-specific settings we have no way to maintain, so those need to come out of the authentication source.
ticket.summary: Quota support [M]

ticket.description:
The software lifecycle specs state that when we release a FileSender code package as a release candidate, it has to run on at least two sites -with a useful number of users- without error for at least 1 week before said release candidate is re-branded as a release. We need a list of sites willing to run release candidate code.
BTW, we *also* need a list of beta-test sites. Sites willing to set up and maintain beta test installs that have a useful user base.
ticket.summary: Get list of FileSender "release candidate test" sites

ticket.description:
n upload_gears.mxml there are a few checks on filesize (and other stuff that's not allowed):
1) fileSize = 0 2) os - Mac and fileSize > 2G 3) fileSize > max_gears_upload_size
In all these cases the user gets the pop up just after selecting the fie (good) *but* in all these cases the selected file is put in the UI and the SEND button appears. So even after the warning (too large) a user still can upload the 'illegal' file by pressing SEND.
The fun part is that this is only when using gears. In the upload_std.mxml (flash upload) everything is OK, the user gets the popup warning, the file-part in the UI is cleared and there is *NO* SEND button to press.
There is some code in upload_gears.mxml that looks like it should prevent the SEND button appearing after a warning but that doesn't seem to do the job.
ticket.summary: Gears fileSize limits can be circumvented

ticket.description: If I have previously selected a 2 GB file, the message "Mac using gears cannot upload a file larger than 2 GB (Error # 032)" is repeated if I subsequently select a zero sized file, then when I click on OK the proper message is revealed "Cannot upload a file of 0 bytes. Please select another file." This was with Gears, on Mac OSX 10.6.7, FF 3.6.16, Flash 10.2.152.33.
ticket.summary: Mac 2GB limit message can appear when selecting zero sized file

ticket.description:
The SURFnet Office IdP replaces the normal SP logout page with a strong security advice when logging out of a service like FileSender. This should warn users that logging out of one specific service doesn't terminate other sessions one might have to other services and also doesn't clear the 'main' session with the identity provider of the user. This makes it possible to login again to FileSender without being asked for credentials. We might want to add a warning about this to the FileSender logout page.
The (a bit technical) text from the SURFet IdP as example: ------------- Due to the nature of this centralized authentication infrastructure and the type of sessions that you have running, it not possible to terminate all of your sessions with each Service Provider with 100% certainty. There is only one option for guaranteed secure logout:
Shutdown your browser when you want to end your running sessions in a secure way!
Apologies for the inconvenience: this is a strong security advice. -------------
Suggestion from Wendy: "Your logout from FileSender is complete. To ensure you have also been logged out from your institutional identity provider, please quit your browser."
Possible bears on the road: - does this cover all cases ? (is every logon to FileSender 'federative'? How about a local u/p database setup?
ticket.summary: Logout warning about still existing 'IdP sessions'

ticket.description:
The concrete use case that triggered this is when someone sends a large file to a mailing list. The receipt email "person X has downloaded file Y" is sent *to* the uploader with a Cc: to the *downloader/recipient*. If the recipient is an email list, the Cc: will go to the email list for every download. If you distribute a file to a list with several 100 people, that is a bit .. annoying.
The difficulty here is to cater for use cases like this without complicating the user interface. A solution might be to have different "filesender user views" depending on which "persona" you are. Using personas is a common technique in user interaction design. You define a limited number of persons with certain characteristics as the people you imagine will use the software and cater to their needs.
For FileSender this might be: a first time user, someone who uses the functionality "as is" and someone who considers him/herself as a "power user" and wants to be able to tweak more of the experience. The first time user would for example have access to a more "guided" approach, a "as is" user knows how to use FileSender but needs no advanced functionality nor does he want to be bothered with the "guided use". The power user would have the option to switch stuff on and off.
This would lead to 3 views on the functionality.
I am tempted to think we need to go that way, as we also need to figure out how to incorporate for example time stamping in the UI.
This requires more thought and more speccing, but at least it is a ticket now....
ticket.summary: Allow uploader to disable download receipt email to file *recipient*

ticket.description:
When using IE8 a Gears upload shows an 'Error on page' warning icon. Uploads are fine though.
"Webpage error details
User Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 6.1; Trident/4.0; SLCC2; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET CLR 3.0.30729; Media Center PC 6.0; InfoPath.2) Timestamp: Thu, 28 Apr 2011 12:11:39 UTC
Message: Request is not loading or done. Line: 221 Char: 3 Code: 0 URI: https://filesender.belnet.be/filesender/js/fs_gears.js " Reported by a Belnet test user and confirmed on a W7/IE8 install at SURFnet
ticket.summary: IE8 JavaScript error

ticket.description: There are two points where the user gets a 'File too large, use Gears' warning using Flash only uploads. The actual messages are not the same. Also the message needs some cleanup (punctuation and clarification about the max size reported). Spotted by Wendy.
ticket.summary: File too large, use Gears warnings inconsistent

ticket.description:
Yesterday I presented CloudStor to about 40 faculty-IT support at NTNU, Trondheim Uni. One of them came with the question whether it was possible, in MyFiles, to extend the expiry time of a file. Say you sent a file to someone, that someone turned out to be on holiday, then you might want to extend the expiry time.
Thoughts: treat this in the way libraries do? Allow for one (or more, such to be configurable) extension of the expiry date, presumably using a button "extend file availability period". Easiest would be if you would have a standard "file availability extension" period. That would be server-configurable as well, and presumably one week would be a good default. However, you can see coming that people would want to just pick a particular date: "I *know* the person will be back on that and that date, so that date + 1 week is good."
This then implies both a button "extend" which does a standard extension plus a calendar which allows a user to set a more specific date. The date box would need to be there anyway to show when the file is about to expire. Having said that, there still ought to be a max expire, also on "extension of availability". By far the easiest way to get started with this appears to be a simple button "extend availability" that simply extends availability with a configurable standard amount of time/days and not let the user pick something.
ticket.summary: Enable expiry time extension

ticket.description:
Some users have "computer fear". So while the FileSender UI is very self-explaining, some users need a little bit of assistance in first time use to allow them to overcome "first use fear".
What I imagine is that a first time user can have some "first use assistance" in the form of for example a little youtube video showing them how FileSender works (in their own language), and possibly a big help button. Something like that.
But this is UI clutter for those people who know quite well how to use it. So hence this ticket: I would like to make it possible that a first time user gets a slightly different UI experience then a second time user. This mechanism can be generalised to offer different groups different "help".
ticket.summary: Multiple User Interface views, guided use vs. normal use

ticket.description:
The second part of "Alias /filesender /usr/share/filesender/www", */usr/share/filesender/www*, must be identical to the path in <Directory> or you get a *403 permision denied* when visiting the webpage and the following error *Log: Directory index forbidden by Options directive: /usr/share/filesender/www* in the apache log.
Furthermore, they both ought to end with *www/* (notice the slash) as if not you get the error *File does not exist: /usr/share/filesender/wwwfilesender* when accessing *http://<domain>/filesender*
ticket.summary: Error in apache.conf included with debian package

ticket.description:
Today a feature request came in from Oslo University which appears to make sense. They would like an option to have a file become available for download *after a certain date+time*. Use cases: any information under embargo until a certain time. Like Call for Tender specs, like PhD thesis, etc.
This would have to wait until we have a good handle on the "how to present advanced functionality to only those users who want/need it without bothering those that don't".
ticket.summary: Allow for a "don't make file available until" date when uploading

ticket.description: When a user tries to upload a file >2GB with a browser that doesn't support that, a message needs to be shown. something like "We're sorry but your browser can not upload files larger then 2GB. Check the list of supported browsers for one that can" but then in proper English. Thought: i am not sure whether this message should link to a page on our assembla site, or whether it should link to a page in the filesender install. It seems it should be the latter: a filesender *service* should not have dependencies on the filesender development site. However: this means that when that page ends, we need to issue an update and get people to run that.
ticket.summary: Add "use different browser" message on upload>2GB in "old" browsers

ticket.description:
When you log on you first get a home page that says something like "FileSender is a secure way to share large files with anyone! Logon to upload your files or invite people to send you a file.".

ticket.description: Displaying the size of a roughly 30GB file as "Size: 31056909312" is a bit straining on the eyes. Like FileSender 1.0 this ought to be "human readable". Human readable labels I would expect are "bytes", "kB", "MB", "GB" and "TB". When running FileSender in debug mode, you might want to be able to see exact number of bytes.

ticket.description: When you upload a Really Big File, say 100GB, it doesn't make sense to let the progress bar hop to 1% the second you start the upload. But it also doesn't make sense to not inform the user the upload has actually started. A way of solving this is to give the user some feedback the second the upload starts. Maybe with the words "upload in progress" in the progress bar? Or with the words "upload in progress" in alternating colours? Something like that?

ticket.description:
1. position: in FileSender 1.0, you pick the file, accept the terms and conditions, and then the progress bar appears underneath the terms of use. In 1.5, the progress bar appears between file details and ToU.
2. label: maybe a good idea to explicitly label the progress bar with "Upload progress"?
3. the progress bar colour in HTML5 is now red/orange. Might be better to have a non-alarm colour there, like green?

ticket.description:
When uploading a file with a voucher in 1.5, if not already logged in some other browser window the voucher issuer doesn't get notified (but should get a bcc). On the server this results in: 
Error: [8] Undefined index:  fileauthuseremail : /var/www/filesender-1.5-svn/classes/Functions.php [787]
When downloading that file also no bcc is sent to the voucher issuer, no errors in the logs though. When logged in as the voucher issuer the upload does generate a bcc (fileauthuseremail is filled in) (not sure about when logged in as another user). In 1.0.1, the bcc is generated for both uploads and downloads whether logged in as the voucher issuer or not logged in, however is not generated if logged in as another user (other than the voucher issuer), possibly because the file is stored in the My Files table of the authenticated voucher recipient not the voucher issuer (see #463).
